    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.signing.key-size=512

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            crypto: 
              signing: 
                key-size    : "512"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.signing.key-size="512" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CRYPTO_SIGNING_KEY_SIZE="512"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.signing.key-size="512"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type=ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN

    • Control the cipher sequence of operations. The accepted values are:

    • ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN: Encrypt the value first, and then sign.
    • SIGN_AND_ENCRYPT: Sign the value first, and then encrypt.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type=ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            crypto: 
              strategy-type    : "ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CRYPTO_STRATEGY_TYPE="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.crypto.alg=

    • The signing/encryption algorithm to use.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.crypto.alg

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.crypto.alg=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          crypto: 
            alg    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.crypto.alg="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CRYPTO_ALG="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.crypto.alg="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.crypto.enabled=true

    • Whether crypto operations are enabled.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.crypto.enabled

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.crypto.enabled=true

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          crypto: 
            enabled    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.crypto.enabled="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CRYPTO_ENABLED="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.crypto.enabled="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption-enabled=true

    • Whether crypto encryption operations are enabled.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

  • cas.authn.oauth.crypto.strategy-type=ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN

    • Control the cipher sequence of operations. The accepted values are:

    • ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN: Encrypt the value first, and then sign.
    • SIGN_AND_ENCRYPT: Sign the value first, and then encrypt.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.crypto.strategy-type

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.crypto.strategy-type=ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          crypto: 
            strategy-type    : "ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.crypto.strategy-type="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CRYPTO_STRATEGY_TYPE="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    • The signing/encryption algorithm to use.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionJwtSigningJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.alg

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.alg=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              crypto: 
                alg    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.alg="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_CRYPTO_ALG="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.alg="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.enabled=true

    • Whether crypto operations are enabled.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionJwtSigningJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.enabled

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.encryption.key-size=512

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              crypto: 
                encryption: 
                  key-size    : "512"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.encryption.key-size="512" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_CRYPTO_ENCRYPTION_KEY_SIZE="512"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.encryption.key-size="512"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key-size=512

    • The signing key size.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.SigningJwtCryptoProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key-size

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key-size=512

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              crypto: 
                signing: 
                  key-size    : "512"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key-size="512" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_CRYPTO_SIGNING_KEY_SIZE="512"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key-size="512"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.strategy-type=ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN

    • Control the cipher sequence of operations. The accepted values are:

    • ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN: Encrypt the value first, and then sign.
    • SIGN_AND_ENCRYPT: Sign the value first, and then encrypt.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionJwtSigningJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.strategy-type

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.strategy-type=ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              crypto: 
                strategy-type    : "ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.strategy-type="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_CRYPTO_STRATEGY_TYPE="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.strategy-type="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.create-as-jwt=false

    • Create access token as JWTs.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthAccessTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.create-as-jwt

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.create-as-jwt=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            create-as-jwt    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.create-as-jwt="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CREATE_AS_JWT="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.create-as-jwt="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.include-claims-in-jwt=true

    • Whether CAS should include extra CAS attributes as claims in the JWT access token. This setting is only relevant if the access token is a determined to be a JWT.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthAccessTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.include-claims-in-jwt

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.include-claims-in-jwt=true

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            include-claims-in-jwt    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.include-claims-in-jwt="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_INCLUDE_CLAIMS_IN_JWT="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.include-claims-in-jwt="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-active-tokens-allowed=0

    • Maximum number of active access tokens that an application can receive. If the application requests more that this limit, the request will be denied and the access token will not be issued.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthAccessTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-active-tokens-allowed

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-active-tokens-allowed=0

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            max-active-tokens-allowed    : "0"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-active-tokens-allowed="0" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_MAX_ACTIVE_TOKENS_ALLOWED="0"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-active-tokens-allowed="0"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-time-to-live-in-seconds=PT8H

    • Hard timeout to kill the access token and expire it.

    This settings supports the java.time.Duration syntax [?].

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthAccessTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-time-to-live-in-seconds

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-time-to-live-in-seconds=PT8H

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            max-time-to-live-in-seconds    : "PT8H"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-time-to-live-in-seconds="PT8H" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_MAX_TIME_TO_LIVE_IN_SECONDS="PT8H"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.max-time-to-live-in-seconds="PT8H"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.storage-name=oauthAccessTokensCache

    • The storage object name used and created by CAS to hold OAuth access tokens in the backing ticket registry implementation.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthAccessTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.storage-name

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.storage-name=oauthAccessTokensCache

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            storage-name    : "oauthAccessTokensCache"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.storage-name="oauthAccessTokensCache" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_STORAGE_NAME="oauthAccessTokensCache"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.storage-name="oauthAccessTokensCache"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds=PT2H

    • Sliding window for the access token expiration policy. Essentially, this is an idle time out.

    This settings supports the java.time.Duration syntax [?].

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthAccessTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds=PT2H

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            time-to-kill-in-seconds    : "PT2H"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds="PT2H" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_TIME_TO_KILL_IN_SECONDS="PT2H"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.code.number-of-uses=1

    • Number of times this code is valid and can be used.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthCodeProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.code.number-of-uses

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.code.number-of-uses=1

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          code: 
            number-of-uses    : "1"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.

    1
2

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.code.remove-related-access-tokens=false

    • Remove the related access tokens when trying to use a code which is expired or no longer exists.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthCodeProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.code.remove-related-access-tokens

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.code.remove-related-access-tokens=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          code: 
            remove-related-access-tokens    : "..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.code.remove-related-access-tokens="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.code.storage-name=oauthCodesCache

    • The storage object name used and created by CAS to hold OAuth codes in the backing ticket registry implementation.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthCodeProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.code.storage-name

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.code.storage-name=oauthCodesCache

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          code: 
            storage-name    : "oauthCodesCache"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.code.storage-name="oauthCodesCache" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CODE_STORAGE_NAME="oauthCodesCache"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.code.storage-name="oauthCodesCache"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.code.time-to-kill-in-seconds=30

    • Duration in seconds where the code is valid.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthCodeProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.code.time-to-kill-in-seconds

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.code.time-to-kill-in-seconds=30

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          code: 
            time-to-kill-in-seconds    : "30"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.code.time-to-kill-in-seconds="30" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CODE_TIME_TO_KILL_IN_SECONDS="30"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.code.time-to-kill-in-seconds="30"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.core.bypass-approval-prompt=false

    • Whether approval prompt/consent screen should be bypassed.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthCoreProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.core.bypass-approval-prompt

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.core.bypass-approval-prompt=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          core: 
            bypass-approval-prompt    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.core.bypass-approval-prompt="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CORE_BYPASS_APPROVAL_PROMPT="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.core.bypass-approval-prompt="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.core.user-profile-view-type=NESTED

    • User profile view type determines how the final user profile should be rendered once an access token is "validated". Available values are as follows:

    • NESTED: Return and render the user profile view in nested mode. This is the default option, most usually.
    • FLAT: Return and render the user profile view in flattened mode where all attributes are flattened down to one level only.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthCoreProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.core.user-profile-view-type

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.core.user-profile-view-type=NESTED

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          core: 
            user-profile-view-type    : "NESTED"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.core.user-profile-view-type="NESTED" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CORE_USER_PROFILE_VIEW_TYPE="NESTED"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.core.user-profile-view-type="NESTED"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.device-token.max-time-to-live-in-seconds=PT5M

    • Hard timeout to kill the device token and expire it.

    This settings supports the java.time.Duration syntax [?].

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthDeviceTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.device-token.max-time-to-live-in-seconds

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    1

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          device-token: 
            max-time-to-live-in-seconds    : "PT5M"

    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_DEVICE_TOKEN_MAX_TIME_TO_LIVE_IN_SECONDS="PT5M"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.device-token.max-time-to-live-in-seconds="PT5M"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.device-token.refresh-interval=PT15S

    • The device refresh interval. The client should attempt to acquire an access token every few seconds (at a rate specified by interval) by POSTing to the access token endpoint on the server.

    This settings supports the java.time.Duration syntax [?].

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthDeviceTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.device-token.refresh-interval

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.device-token.refresh-interval=PT15S

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          device-token: 
            refresh-interval    : "PT15S"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.device-token.refresh-interval="PT15S" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_DEVICE_TOKEN_REFRESH_INTERVAL="PT15S"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
