  • cas.authn.oauth.grants.resource-owner.require-service-header=false

    • Whether using the resource-owner grant should enforce authorization rules and per-service policies based on a service parameter is provided as a header outside the normal semantics of the grant and protocol.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthGrantsProperties.ResourceOwner.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.grants.resource-owner.require-service-header

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.grants.resource-owner.require-service-header=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          grants: 
            resource-owner: 
              require-service-header    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.grants.resource-owner.require-service-header="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_GRANTS_RESOURCE_OWNER_REQUIRE_SERVICE_HEADER="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.grants.resource-owner.require-service-header="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.create-as-jwt=false

    • Create access token as JWTs.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthRefreshTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.create-as-jwt

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.create-as-jwt=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          refresh-token: 
            create-as-jwt    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.create-as-jwt="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_REFRESH_TOKEN_CREATE_AS_JWT="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.create-as-jwt="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.max-active-tokens-allowed=0

    • Maximum number of active refresh tokens that an application can receive. If the application requests more that this limit, the request will be denied and the access token will not be issued.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthRefreshTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.max-active-tokens-allowed

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.max-active-tokens-allowed=0

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          refresh-token: 
            max-active-tokens-allowed    : "0"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.max-active-tokens-allowed="0" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_REFRESH_TOKEN_MAX_ACTIVE_TOKENS_ALLOWED="0"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.max-active-tokens-allowed="0"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.storage-name=oauthRefreshTokensCache

    • The storage object name used and created by CAS to hold OAuth refresh tokens in the backing ticket registry implementation.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthRefreshTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.storage-name

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.storage-name=oauthRefreshTokensCache

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          refresh-token: 
            storage-name    : "oauthRefreshTokensCache"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.storage-name="oauthRefreshTokensCache" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_REFRESH_TOKEN_STORAGE_NAME="oauthRefreshTokensCache"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.storage-name="oauthRefreshTokensCache"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds=P14D

    • Hard timeout beyond which the refresh token is considered expired.

    This settings supports the java.time.Duration syntax [?].

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthRefreshTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds=P14D

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          refresh-token: 
            time-to-kill-in-seconds    : "P14D"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds="P14D" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_REFRESH_TOKEN_TIME_TO_KILL_IN_SECONDS="P14D"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.time-to-kill-in-seconds="P14D"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.track-access-tokens=true

    • If true, the refresh token will keep track of the access tokens issued using it. The access tokens will remain attached to the refresh token as long as the refresh token is valid and they are not periodically on on-demand checked for validity or removed from the refresh token if they expire. The tracking mechanism is only for history and auditing purposes.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.oauth.OAuthRefreshTokenProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.track-access-tokens

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.track-access-tokens=true

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          refresh-token: 
            track-access-tokens    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.track-access-tokens="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_REFRESH_TOKEN_TRACK_ACCESS_TOKENS="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.refresh-token.track-access-tokens="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.allowed-ip-addresses-pattern=

    • A regular expression pattern that indicates the set of allowed IP addresses, when #isPinToSession() is configured. In the event that there is a mismatch between the cookie IP address and the current request-provided IP address (i.e. network switches, VPN, etc), the cookie can still be considered valid if the new IP address matches the pattern specified here.

    This settings supports regular expression patterns. [?].

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.allowed-ip-addresses-pattern

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.allowed-ip-addresses-pattern=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              allowed-ip-addresses-pattern    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.allowed-ip-addresses-pattern="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_ALLOWED_IP_ADDRESSES_PATTERN="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.allowed-ip-addresses-pattern="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.auto-configure-cookie-path=true

    • Decide if cookie paths should be automatically configured based on the application context path, when the cookie path is not configured. Deprecation: since 7.3.0

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.auto-configure-cookie-path

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.auto-configure-cookie-path=true

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              auto-configure-cookie-path    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.auto-configure-cookie-path="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_AUTO_CONFIGURE_COOKIE_PATH="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.auto-configure-cookie-path="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.domain=

    • Cookie domain. Specifies the domain within which this cookie should be presented. The form of the domain name is specified by RFC 2965. A domain name begins with a dot (.foo.com) and means that the cookie is visible to servers in a specified Domain Name System (DNS) zone (for example, www.foo.com, but not a.b.foo.com). By default, cookies are only returned to the server that sent them.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.domain

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.geo-locate-client-session=false

    • When set to true and assuming #isPinToSession() is also true, client sessions (using the client IP address) are geo-located using a geolocation service when/if configured. The resulting session is either pinned to the client geolocation, or the default client address.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.geo-locate-client-session

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • YAML Property
    • System Property

  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.http-only=true

    • true if this cookie contains the HttpOnly attribute. This means that the cookie should not be accessible to scripting engines, like javascript.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.http-only

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.http-only="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_HTTP_ONLY="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.http-only="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.max-age=-1

    • The maximum age of the cookie, specified in seconds. By default, -1 indicating the cookie will persist until browser shutdown. A positive value indicates that the cookie will expire after that many seconds have passed. Note that the value is the maximum age when the cookie will expire, not the cookie's current age. A negative value means that the cookie is not stored persistently and will be deleted when the Web browser exits. A zero value causes the cookie to be deleted.

    This settings supports the java.time.Duration syntax [?].

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.max-age

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.max-age=-1

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              max-age    : "-1"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.max-age="-1" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_MAX_AGE="-1"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.max-age="-1"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.name=

    • Cookie name. Constructs a cookie with a specified name and value. The name must conform to RFC 2965. That means it can contain only ASCII alphanumeric characters and cannot contain commas, semicolons, or white space or begin with a $ character. The cookie's name cannot be changed after creation. By default, cookies are created according to the RFC 2965 cookie specification. Cookie names are automatically calculated assigned by CAS at runtime, and there is usually no need to customize the name or assign it a different value unless a special use case warrants the change.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.name

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.name=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              name    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.name="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_NAME="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.name="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.path=

    • Cookie path. Specifies a path for the cookie to which the client should return the cookie. The cookie is visible to all the pages in the directory you specify, and all the pages in that directory's subdirectories. A cookie's path must include the servlet that set the cookie, for example, /catalog, which makes the cookie visible to all directories on the server under /catalog. Consult RFC 2965 (available on the Internet) for more information on setting path names for cookies.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.path

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.pin-to-session=true

    • When generating cookie values, determine whether the value should be compounded and signed with the properties of the current session, such as IP address, user-agent, etc.

    Turning off session pinning is not exactly ideal. This is a barrier to prevent cookie replay attacks. A cookie that was created with an IP given a certain location cannot be replayed back in a different browser with a different IP from a different location.

    There may however be legitimate reasons to turn it off and relax this after careful reviews, if you intend to support a type of user who intends to switch their IP quite frequently. A classic example is the type of user that is on VPN at the time of login, but decides to resume their work a few hours later off VPN or at a different location.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.pin-to-session

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    1

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              pin-to-session    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.pin-to-session="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_PIN_TO_SESSION="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.pin-to-session="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.same-site-policy=

    • If a cookie is only intended to be accessed in a first party context, the developer has the option to apply one of settings SameSite=Lax or SameSite=Strict or SameSite=None to prevent external access.

    To safeguard more websites and their users, the new secure-by-default model assumes all cookies should be protected from external access unless otherwise specified. Developers must use a new cookie setting, SameSite=None, to designate cookies for cross-site access. When the SameSite=None attribute is present, an additional Secure attribute is used so cross-site cookies can only be accessed over HTTPS connections.

    Accepted values are:
    • Lax
    • Strict
    • None
    • Off: Disable the generation of the SameSite cookie attribute altogether.
    • Path to a Groovy script that is able to generate the SameSite cookie attribute dynamically.
    • Fully qualified name of a class that implements org.apereo.cas.web.cookie.CookieSameSitePolicy

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.same-site-policy

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

              same-site-policy    : "..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.

    1

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.secure=true

    • True if sending this cookie should be restricted to a secure protocol, or false if the it can be sent using any protocol.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.support.replication.CookieSessionReplicationProperties.

  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption.key=

    • The encryption key is a string whose length is defined by the encryption key size setting.

    This setting supports the Spring Expression Language.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionJwtCryptoProperties.

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.crypto.signing.key="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CRYPTO_SIGNING_KEY="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.crypto.signing.key="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.encryption.key=

    • The encryption key is a string whose length is defined by the encryption key size setting.

    This setting supports the Spring Expression Language.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionJwtCryptoProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.encryption.key

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.encryption.key=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              crypto: 
                encryption: 
                  key    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.encryption.key="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_CRYPTO_ENCRYPTION_KEY="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.encryption.key="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key=

    • The signing key is a string whose length is defined by the signing key size setting.

    This setting supports the Spring Expression Language.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.SigningJwtCryptoProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          session-replication: 
            cookie: 
              crypto: 
                signing: 
                  key    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_SESSION_REPLICATION_COOKIE_CRYPTO_SIGNING_KEY="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.session-replication.cookie.crypto.signing.key="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.alg=

    • The signing/encryption algorithm to use.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.alg

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.alg=...

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            crypto: 
              alg    : "..."

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.alg="..." -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CRYPTO_ALG="..."

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.alg="..."

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.enabled=true

    • Whether crypto operations are enabled.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.enabled

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.enabled=true

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            crypto: 
              enabled    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.enabled="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CRYPTO_ENABLED="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.enabled="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption-enabled=true

    • Whether crypto encryption operations are enabled.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption-enabled

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption-enabled=true

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            crypto: 
              encryption-enabled    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption-enabled="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CRYPTO_ENCRYPTION_ENABLED="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption-enabled="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption.key-size=512

    • The encryption key size.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionJwtCryptoProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption.key-size

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption.key-size=512

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            crypto: 
              encryption: 
                key-size    : "512"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption.key-size="512" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CRYPTO_ENCRYPTION_KEY_SIZE="512"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.encryption.key-size="512"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    • Whether crypto signing operations are enabled.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.signing-enabled

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            crypto: 
              signing-enabled    : "true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CRYPTO_SIGNING_ENABLED="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type=ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN

    • Control the cipher sequence of operations. The accepted values are:

    • ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN: Encrypt the value first, and then sign.
    • SIGN_AND_ENCRYPT: Sign the value first, and then encrypt.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type=ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          access-token: 
            crypto: 
              strategy-type    : "ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_ACCESS_TOKEN_CRYPTO_STRATEGY_TYPE="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.access-token.crypto.strategy-type="ENCRYPT_AND_SIGN"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

          crypto: 
            enabled    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.crypto.enabled="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CRYPTO_ENABLED="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.crypto.enabled="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption-enabled=true

    • Whether crypto encryption operations are enabled.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption-enabled

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    • Java Property
    • YAML Property
    • System Property
    • Environment Variable
    • Command-line Argument

    CAS properties can be specified using the Java configuration property syntax in any and all .properties files: 

    

    1

    		

    cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption-enabled=true

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.
    CAS properties can be specified using the YAML syntax:

    

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          crypto: 
            encryption-enabled    : "true"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as system properties, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption-enabled="true" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.
    CAS properties can specified as system environment variables before the CAS web application is launched: 

    

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CRYPTO_ENCRYPTION_ENABLED="true"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
    CAS properties can be passed to the CAS web application as command-line arguments, when the application is launched: 

    

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption-enabled="true"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption.key-size=512

    • The encryption key size.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionJwtCryptoProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption.key-size

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    This is the most common form of property configuration that is recognized by CAS, regardless of the actual property source, which might in fact be managed separately outside the CAS environment, by another system or cloud framework.

    1

    		

    cas: 
      authn: 
        oauth: 
          crypto: 
            encryption: 
              key-size    : "512"

    Note that YAML is very specific about structure and indentation. Be sure to verify the correctness of the final result with your YAML validator of choice.

    java -Dcas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption.key-size="512" -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory. Note the placement of the system property which must be specified before the CAS web application is launched.

    1
2
3

    		

    export CAS_AUTHN_OAUTH_CRYPTO_ENCRYPTION_KEY_SIZE="512"

java -jar build/libs/cas.war

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    1

    		

    java -jar build/libs/cas.war --cas.authn.oauth.crypto.encryption.key-size="512"

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
  • cas.authn.oauth.crypto.signing-enabled=true

    • Whether crypto signing operations are enabled.

    org.apereo.cas.configuration.model.core.util.EncryptionOptionalSigningOptionalJwtCryptographyProperties.

    How can I configure this property?

    CAS Property: cas.authn.oauth.crypto.signing-enabled

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    Note

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.

    Configuration properties can be included and activated using the following strategies.

    When possible, properties should be stored in lower-case kebab format, such as cas.property-name=value. The only possible exception to this rule is when naming actuator endpoints; The name of the actuator endpoints (i.e. ssoSessions) MUST remain in camelCase mode.

    The above example assumes that the CAS web application is packaged as cas.war with an embedded server container and can be found in the build/libs directory.
